Basic Usage¶

Tasker is a text based task manager that runs at the command line or within Python. It is written in Python 3.5 but will most likely run in earlier versions.

Tasker manager manages two files: todo.txt and done.txt. Each task is saved on a single line in either file. Tasker follows the task formatting rules set out by Gina Trapani’s Todo.txt format with the addition of using full datetime stamps instead of just dates.

The Anatomy of a Task¶

Tasks consist of a single line of text:

  • ‘x ‘ if the task is completed
  • ‘(p)’ if the task has a priority. Priorities are A-Z.
  • ‘datetime stamp’ for the start of the task (default to time task is created)
  • ‘datetime stamp’ for the time the task was completed (if completed)
  • remaining text is the actual task

Tasks are organized by projects (words that begin with ‘+’) and contexts (words that begin with ‘@’). Tasks may also have extensions which are key:value pairs wrapped in brackets (for example {uid:221112080316}).

Here is an example of a pending task:

(A) 2016-03-08T09:51:38 Finish +TaskerDocumentation @code # It's getting late

This task has a priority. It has a project (TaskerDocumentation) and a context (code) and a comment.

Here is an example of a completed task:

x 2016-03-07T11:45:08 2016-03-08T21:35:12 Call mom @phone

This task is complete and won’t appear in the task list unless requested.

Note

Samples in this document

In the command line samples, only a simple prompt > is presented for the command line.

The interactive prompts include their name.

> t list and tasker> list are the same thing, the first from the command line and the second from the interactive prompt.

Basic Commands¶

The three basic commands are list, add, and do. If no command is given, the program lists all open tasks:

> tasker
1 2016-03-04T22:04:30 test from cli
2 2015-03-06T19:37:12 test add
--
2 tasks shown

> tasker add go to bed
'2016-04-08T22:11:12 go to bed {uid:221112080316}'

> tasker list
1 2016-03-04T22:04:30 test from cli
2 2016-03-06T19:37:12 test add
5 2016-03-08T22:11:12 go to bed
--
3 tasks shown

> tasker do 1
'x 2016-03-08T22:16:02 2016-03-08T22:16:01 test from cli {uid:220430040316}'

> tasker
2 2016-03-06T19:27:12 test add
5 2016-03-08T22:11:12 go to bed
--
2 tasks shown

Tasker adds a uid extension to each task it creates but does not list this when it prints the task list. The uid is used to chain tasks together.

Note

Task Numbers

Task numbers are simply the line number in the current file. This provides a quick reference to tasks. Be warned that archiving tasks will renumber your files.

Note

Tasker comes with a Windows batch file that runs the Python script directly. It can be used so t is a shortcut to Tasker.py.

Interactive Mode¶

You can also run tasker in an interactive prompt:

>t -i
tasker> list
2 2016-03-06T19:27:12 test add
5 2016-03-08T22:11:12 go to bed
--
2 tasks shown

For most commands, the interactive prompt uses the same input as the command line interface.

Listing Tasks¶

The simple list command will show only currently open tasks, but you can filter tasks by including search terms:

> t
13 (B) 2016-03-20T18:33:23 Get complete information for +HomeQuote @quote
12 2016-03-17T22:54:20 redo +Documentation
16 2016-03-21T20:57:51 third useless thing
---
3 tasks shown

> t list thing
16 2016-03-21T20:57:51 third useless thing
---
1 tasks shown

> t list information
13 (B) 2016-03-20T18:33:23 Get complete information for +HomeQuote @quote
---
1 tasks shown

However, if you try to search for more than one keyword, tasker will only list open tasks that match all those keywords:

> t list thing information
0 tasks shown

You can use the -y flag to match any filter keyword:

> t list -y thing information
13 (B) 2016-03-20T18:33:23 Get complete information for +HomeQuote @quote
16 2016-03-21T20:57:51 third useless thing
---
2 tasks shown

Sorting Tasks¶

The default behavior is to list tasks by priority. Using the -n switch will display tasks in numerical order:

> t list -n
12 2016-03-17T22:54:20 redo +Documentation
13 (B) 2016-03-20T18:33:23 Get complete information for +HomeQuote @quote
16 2016-03-21T20:57:51 third useless thing
---
3 tasks shown

Showing Completed Tasks¶

The default behavior is to only list open tasks, but you can see completed tasks with the -x switch:

> t list -a
13 (B) 2016-03-20T18:33:23 Get complete information for +HomeQuote @quote
12 2016-03-17T22:54:20 redo +Documentation
16 2016-03-21T20:57:51 third useless thing
 2 x 2016-03-06T19:27:12 2016-03-21T20:52:25 test add # test complete
...
---
16 tasks shown

Showing Extensions¶

The default behavior is to hide extensions that are used by the program to relate tasks to each other. You can show these extensions with the -x switch:

> t list -x
13 (B) 2016-03-20T18:33:23 Get complete information for +HomeQuote @quote
       {wn:quote} {ws:2} {wid:5} {uid:183323200316}
12 2016-03-17T22:54:20 redo +Documentation {uid:225420170316}
16 2016-03-21T20:57:51 third useless thing {uid:205751210316}
---
3 tasks shown

Note

The list command uses text wrap to a default of 78 characters.

Adding Tasks¶

The default behavior is to add whatever text you include. However, if x is the first character of the new task, it will be created as a closed task:

> t add x is this complete?
x 2016-03-22T21:39:42 2016-03-22T21:39:42 is this complete? {uid:213942220316}

> t
13 (B) 2016-03-20T18:33:23 Get complete information for +HomeQuote @quote
12 2016-03-17T22:54:20 redo +Documentation
16 2016-03-21T20:57:51 third useless thing
---
3 tasks shown

> t list -a complete
17 x 2016-03-22T21:39:42 2016-03-22T21:39:42 is this complete?
---
1 tasks shown

Marking tasks as Complete¶

You can close a task with the do command. The input string should be the TASK NUMBER and any EXTRA COMMENT.

> t 32 2016-03-24T15:30:19 unprioritized task # This should be done soon — 1 task shown

> t do 32 This is now done x 2016-03-24T15:30:19 2016-03-24T15:43:52 unprioritized task {uid:153019240316} # This should be done soon # This is now done

> t 0 tasks shown

List Projects and Contexts¶

It is also possible to list your open and closed projects:

> t projects
No open projects.

> t projects --closed
Project             Open Closed
------------------- ---- ------
+BogusQuote         0    5
+BookingsAdjustment 0    1
...
+SaratogaEval       0    1
+TMQuotes           0    1
NO PROJECT          0    14

> t contexts
No open contexts.

> t contexts --closed
Context    Open Closed
---------- ---- ------
@bookings  0    1
@orders    0    1
@quote     0    19
@test      0    2
NO CONTEXT 0    13

Changing Task Priorities¶

You can change the priority of a task by using the pri command:

> t
32 2016-03-24T15:30:19 unprioritized task
---
1 task shown

> t pri 32 A This should be done soon
(A) 2016-03-24T15:30:19 unprioritized task {uid:153019240316} # This should be done soon

> t
32 (A) 2016-03-24T15:30:19 unprioritized task # This should be done soon
---
1 task shown

You can remove the proirity on a task using an underscore:

> t pri 32 _
 2016-03-24T15:30:19 unprioritized task {uid:153019240316} # This should be done soon

Getting Details on the Process¶

You can get more information about what Tasker is doing using the -v flag on the command line. You can use -vv to get debugging information as well.

If you use these flags to enter the interactive prompt, they will be in effect for the length of your session.

You can get less information by using the -q flag, and even less information about errors with -qq.

Todo Manager

usage: t [-h] [-i] [--wrap {wrap,shorten,none}] [--width WIDTH] [-z] [-l]
         [-d | -v | -q]
         ...
Options:
-i=False, --interactive=False
 enter the interactive loop
--wrap=wrap

Undocumented

Possible choices: wrap, shorten, none

--width=78 Width to wrap or shorten text when printing
-z=True Hides Z-priority tasks
-l=True Shows Z-priority tasks before unprioritized tasks
-d=0, --debug=0
 show all debug messages
-v=0, --verbose=0
 show more process details (can repeat)
-q=0, --quiet=0
 show fewer process details (can repeat)
Sub-commands:
list

list tasks

Tool for listing tasks

usage: t list [-h] [-n] [-y] [-a] [-x] ...
Positional arguments:
filters Only lists tasks containing these words
Options:
-n=True Prints task list in numerical order, otherwise orders by priority
-y=False Shows tasks matching any filter word. Default is to match all
-a=False Show completed (but not archived) tasks.
-x=False Shows hidden text extensions
add

add a task

usage: t add [-h] [-d] text [text ...]
Positional arguments:
text text of the new task
Options:
-d=False, --done=False
 Adds task as completed
do

mark a task as complete

usage: t do [-h] tasknum ...
Positional arguments:
tasknum number of the task to complete
comment comment to add to the completed task
pri

prioritize a task

usage: t pri [-h] tasknum priority ...
Positional arguments:
tasknum number of the task to prioritize
priority letter of new priority or _ to clear
note optional note to attach to task
plugins

Plugin manager

usage: t plugins [-h] {list,activate,deactivate,categories,create} ...
Sub-commands:
list

List the known plugins

usage: t plugins list [-h]
activate

Activate plugins by name

usage: t plugins activate [-h] name
Positional arguments:
name name of the plugin to activate
deactivate

Deactivate plugin by name

usage: t plugins deactivate [-h] name
Positional arguments:
name name of the plugin to deactivate
categories

list current plugin categories

usage: t plugins categories [-h]
create

Create a new plugin

usage: t plugins create [-h] name {new,sub,generic}
Positional arguments:
name name of the plugin to template
kind

The kind of plugin to template

Possible choices: new, sub, generic
archive

Archive commands

usage: t archive [-h]  ...
Sub-commands:
project

Archive by project

usage: t archive project [-h] [--days DAYS] ...
Positional arguments:
projects names of Projects to archive
Options:
--days=3 minimum age of closed tasks to archive

For more information use the –manual flag
